text.p: The following are top headlines from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Ontario doctors reject tentative deal: Ontario Medical Association decides to delay job action if government resumes talks.
- Tutsi offensive imperils Hutus: UN seeks safety for aid workers.
- Health issue baffles Ontario government: No recognition for funding rise.
- Automakers propose airbag redesign: Safety device to deploy with less force in bid to reduce injuries, deaths.
- After half a century, Toronto radio morning man signing off.
- Foreign bank rules assailed: Parliamentary committees urge Canadian government to loosen entry restrictions, increase competition.
- Pepsi dumps ad agency of 30 years: Thompson loses account to BBDO.
- Gulf Canada Resources chief defends job relocation: J.P. Bryan cites job stress, Calgary sees 'slap in the face.'
- Lumber firms get quotas: Ottawa releases duty-free levels.
- Canadian seeks more concessions: Route restructurings, wage cuts and breaks on fees for AMR services are among the items on Canadian Airlines' shopping list.
